instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the classification models in the study to detect adulterated flaxseed oils and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the classification models in the past study is conditional entropy. This metric measures the amount of information gained about the class labels given the values of certain features. It quantifies the uncertainty in the classification process and indicates how well the features can discriminate between different classes.

The study mentions that using machine learning algorithms with conditional entropy, two or three wavenumbers/shifts could discriminate the oils with an accuracy of over 95%. This suggests that the chosen metric, conditional entropy, is able to effectively evaluate the classification models and provide accurate results in identifying the pureness of oils.

instruction: How were the oil spectra analyzed in the past study on developing a machine learning algorithm and information theory to detect adulterated flaxseed oils using vibrational spectroscopy units combined with chemometrics?
Output: The oil spectra in the past study were analyzed using conditional entropy, support vector machines (SVM), soft independent modeling of class analogy (SIMCA), and partial least square regression (PLSR). Conditional entropy was used to determine the discriminatory power of specific wavenumbers/shifts in distinguishing between pure and adulterated oils. SVM and SIMCA were employed to generate classification models for identifying the pureness of oils, with SIMCA models using an interclass distance (ICD) threshold of 1.1. PLSR was used to predict the levels of adulterants and fatty acid distributions in the oils. The Fourier transform mid-infrared (FT-MIR) unit was found to provide the best classification performance with an ICD over 4.9. Overall, these methods and techniques allowed for the rapid and accurate identification of adulterated flaxseed oils.
